name: Stephen Carney
text:
Bad service, meh atmosphere, good food.

Atmosphere:
Went for lunch on a Friday, not very busy. Five of us were seated at a bar top for four. The table and a couple chairs were wobbly so a few of us felt like we were seated on a water bed. An employee noticed, left for a few minutes, came back and tried to level the table, made it worse, cursed a little, and gave up. We probably should have asked to move but we got used to it by the time we realized he wasn’t coming back. TVs were playing some daytime drama on mute. Never understood why restaurants choose this over sports or the news.

Service:
Frustratingly slow, unenthusiastic. There were actually plenty of employees there, just not sure what most of them were doing. One guy was working the bar, waiting tables, and delivering food. We could tell he wasn’t happy about it. The others seemed to pitch in here and there. We ordered a couple of pies which took about 40 minutes to come out.

Food:
The pizza was quite good. Definite quality stuff, but not special enough to offset the otherwise sad experience. To quote one of my colleagues, “that was actually pretty good! It’s too bad I’ll never have it again.”

name: Gregory Calabrese
text:
Extremely disappointed with the pizza at Anthony's coal fired pizza.  Crust was way too thick, overly salty while slathered with much too much sauce.  Did I say that it is too salty?   Then there was too much oil on or in bottom of the crust.  The whole thing was massively wrong headed.   This is pizza engineered for backwater southern malls where people grew up eating microwave chicken nuggets and #1 burger combos. These backwater types have had their tastes engineered to love salty and greasy.  Anthony's delivers on both counts.  Salty and greasy.  Not greasy in the good way.  One look at the clientele here and this is validated.

Anthony's is massively salty.  Piling on the salt is a quick and easy way to season food for backwater bumpkins that do not know any better.  This pizza is massively over-loaded with salt both in the crust AND the sauce.  New Yorkers should know better.    Low-quality pizza like this does not belong in New York which has the legacy of New York City.  The NYC pizza tradition  goes back 100+ years and some say better pizza than Italia.    In an all out pizza war Anthony's Coal Fired is a G.I. Joe toy.  Totally out classed in the New York Pizza scene which has so many powerhouse pizzerias.  Try Zaza nearby.  Shocking that low-quality pizza like Anthony's appears to be succeeding in the NYC region.  This speaks to the declining tastes of the locals.  To be fair there is good service here from the very helpful friendly staff and the decor is nice.  Just don't confuse this place as a venue for edible pizza.
